Definition: A controlled research environment specifically designed for standardized data collection or experimentation.
A healthcare setting where data are collected as part of clinical care or clinical research activities.
A real-world setting outside controlled laboratory or clinical environments (e.g., community, workplace, school).
A participant’s personal residence where data collection occurs.
A setting in which data collection occurs without in-person contact, mediated by digital or communication technologies.
Data collection occurs across multiple administration contexts.
The administration context is not known or not recorded.

Study determined to be exempt from IRB review
IRB review or consent requirements waived
IRB review not required under applicable regulations

Metadata aims to cover all data types collected for the study, including those not available for external sharing.
Metadata includes only data types that are available for external access requests.
Metadata covers some collected data types beyond those shareable, but is not intended to be exhaustive.
Scope is not known or not specified.
The principal investigator who initially established or led the study at its start.
The principal investigator currently responsible for the study’s scientific leadership.
An individual who shares principal investigator responsibilities with another PI.
A temporary or interim principal investigator responsible during a transition period.
More than one PI role applies or multiple PI roles are represented but not specified.

Participants are selected to represent a general or normative population without requiring a specific disease or elevated risk status.
Participants are selected based on elevated risk for a condition (e.g., family history, exposure, prodromal symptoms) but may not meet diagnostic criteria.
Participants are selected because they have a specified disease or condition (or meet defined clinical criteria for that condition).
The study includes two or more contrasting groups (e.g., cases vs controls, condition vs normative, multiple conditions) to enable comparison.
Participants are identified through registries or administrative/health record sources where cohort definition is driven by existing records rather than direct recruitment.
Participants were enrolled without requiring a specific diagnosis or elevated risk status at baseline.
Participants were enrolled because they met criteria for a specified disease/condition at baseline.
Participants were enrolled based on elevated risk indicators (e.g., family history, exposure, symptom threshold) without necessarily meeting diagnostic criteria.
The study enrolled two or more baseline health groups (e.g., condition and normative, or multiple conditions) for comparison.
Participants were recruited or identified from community sources outside of clinical care settings (e.g., advertisements, schools, workplaces).
Participants were recruited or identified through clinical care settings (e.g., clinics, hospitals, specialty practices).
Participants were identified using existing administrative sources or registries (e.g., EHR systems, claims data, disease registries).
Participants were recruited or identified using a combination of community, clinic, and/or administrative/registry sources.
Enrollment used minimal inclusion/exclusion criteria beyond basic eligibility (e.g., age range, consent capacity).
Enrollment applied multiple inclusion/exclusion criteria that narrow eligibility but remain relatively general.
Enrollment applied stringent or specialized inclusion/exclusion criteria (e.g., specific phenotype thresholds, comorbidity exclusions, protocol adherence requirements).
The restrictiveness of enrollment criteria is not known or not recorded.
IRB oversight pertains to the original conduct of the study (initial enrollment and primary data collection).
IRB oversight pertains to secondary analysis of previously collected data (e.g., reuse of an existing dataset).
IRB oversight pertains to a specific site within a multi-site study (e.g., local IRB approvals).
IRB oversight pertains to sharing or reuse of data outside the original study context (e.g., repository deposition or downstream reuse).
Consent permits future research use without restriction to specific diseases or narrowly defined purposes.
Consent permits some types of research uses while restricting others (i.e., multiple allowed-use options are specified).
Consent limits data use to a specific disease, condition, purpose, or study context.
Consent does not permit sharing beyond the original study team or stated original purpose.
Consent type is not known or not recorded.
Direct identifiers were removed according to HIPAA Safe Harbor criteria.
An expert assessed and documented that re-identification risk is sufficiently low under applicable standards.
Direct identifiers were replaced with codes while a re-identification key may exist under separate control.
Identifiers were removed or transformed such that re-identification is not reasonably possible.
Data were shared as a HIPAA limited dataset (some indirect identifiers such as dates may be retained under agreement).
